comments.commentBody:
A "strident" atheist is one who says out loud that they don't believe in god. It's been my experience that stridency is much more prevalent among believers, including many priests, but only atheists get smeared with “strident.”

It is a false equivalency to say that certainty of a god is on a par with not believing in a god. If there is to be a contest, the onus is on believers to prove the insupportable things they are certain of. Typically, an atheist concedes that they will believe once someone produces evidence. Conversely, it is typical of believers that no amount of evidence contradicting their religion’s tenets could change their minds. Ben Carson, a physician(!), believes the earth is 5,000 years old. There is no equivalent absurdity among atheists. Religion carries on despite conflicting evidence. It is religion that needs repair, not atheism.

If believers want peace and comity with people who beliefs diverge from theirs, they ought to stop trying to impose their beliefs on others. But if they persist, they will get serious stridency in response. I am under no obligation—ethically, morally, or legally—to embrace anybody else’s beliefs, or to make concessions to them.

I am an agnostic, and while I do not believe in any God, I do wonder sometimes if I am wrong about that.  I find it hard to credit either a believer or a prefessed non-believer who claims to be so certain of the rightness of his beliefs.

As an atheist, I really hate this essay. Don't tell me what I believe, and don't tell me that you know I have doubts about my atheism. I don't. I give the existence of some kind of God as much credence as Russel's orbiting export (or its latest incarnation, the FSM). As another commenter astutely said, claims advanced without evidence can be dismissed without evidence. The burden is on the believers to provide evidence for their ridiculous ideas.

There is no equivalence between making fantastic claims without evidence, and asking for evidence before believing the aforementioned fantastic claims.

Actually, your sarcasm serves to make Donald Trump's points exactly. Americans have been told for decades that free trade would ultimately lift the U.S. economy. I am not a fan of Trump at all and, his reactionary tactics are absurd. However, the trade surpluses you cite are miniscle relative the the deficits with other countries while our overall collective deficit is unsustainable and can't be wished away to "greatness". You are ignoring the magnitude of the problem.

As the economic donut gets larger, so does its hole. And, into this hole we pour tremendous amounts of revenue (much of it borrowed) to pay for the "too good to be true" prices of cheap imported goods. Those hidden costs are reflected in crime, subsidies and social programs for the un/underemployed, welfare, food stamps, and community blight and my taxes, at least, are staggering.

The American people do not feel we have gotten a fair deal from free trade and despite some data to the contrary, the trendline outlook is not good. Yes, Donald is wrong and yes, not every one here is an economist but, your summary dismissal of their concerns is why Mr. Trump is doing as well as he is. I have not seen many comments suggesting simple solutions or, trade isolationism. For those who are un/underemployed, it is undeniable that we do need "a better deal" because the scorecard (reflected in our debt and deficit) says we are losing.

The US economy has been on a military footing since 1941. Look at the proportion of US GDP devoted to the military and the production of war material, and the subsidies to the companies involved. Look at figures for US arms and aircraft sales worldwide. Changing this model would plunge the US, and the world economy, into an abyss. The business of the US is war.

Trump's attitude toward international trade underscores the man's appeal, and his limitations. He's popular because of his simplistic solution to trade deficits--i.e., tariffs--which everyone can understand. Unfortunately, he's scary for the same reason. Tariffs cut both ways, which he fails to appreciate.

For a man who touts his business acumen, he's astoundingly ignorant of the repercussions of his proposals.

Balance is still very much needed. The only way we as a society can go on with this utterly indefensible hemorrhage of jobs is unequivocal redistribution of resources(a la Bernie Sanders). Bernie is great, but his policies are just a start.

And in the same breathe I would go go even further than Mr. Sanders as this wage shedding metastasizes throughout the entire 0-80% income bracket: a minimum income.

Jobs are a thing of the past if we keep heading in the direction we're going(and as stated not even Bernie Sanders would deviate us from this course), left to only the privileged few(software programmers, professional workers, "event planners", you get the idea...). If we do not address fluidity at the bottom and middle of all wage earners, well let's just say there will be blood. I hope only metaphorically, but perhaps not...

Martin, we had the kids over tonight. We had stone crabs, shrimp cocktail, Honey Baked Ham and all the sides and appetizers. After they were gone I started watching Easter Parade. I hate musicals and so does the Wife. But I love an artist like Astaire and once I started watching the Wife got hooked. So we are now watching that CLASSIC. I cannot believe the Wife and I are watching it together. I guess that’s what happens after 52 years of living together.

wow and to think I used to think Irwin knew his subject. while the basic framework of some of his arguments is correct, some of his other "logical" responses to say, where the chinese would choose to spend the money they make off of us, ie buying real estate here or t-bills instead of say, gold or other commodity is a typical economist "just-so" argument. and utterly preposterous. you want to fix the trade deficit overnight? here's how;

1. pass the I Love America and Cute Puppies Act of 2016. the act requires that ANY american corporation moving jobs overseas must also domicile at least 25 of their 100 highest paid management personnel in that country else corporate tax rate doubles. overnight.
2. pass the Apple Pie and I Love Mom Act of 2016. that act allows any american with overseas profits squirreled away (I'm talking to you Apple) they have until November 1, 2016 to repatriate the profits at the present tax rate. because on 2 Nov, the tax rate doubles.

chew on those points greedy, crooked corporate america. we dont need a trump to straighten these guys out. all we need is a congress with spine who are not full of bought and paid for corporate tools.

The one word I'll contend that Connie missed was "good" (jobs). Yes, there are lots of minimum wage jobs out there, not so many of the old middle-class manufacturing jobs.

That said, I'm not totally convinced (thanks in part to Irwin's article) that the problem is simply the trade deficit. Perhaps a more accurate contention is that the gains from the trade deficit (and automation) have mostly gone to the 1%.

There are gains from trade deficits (e.g. low interest rates, as the article pointed out). The problem, it strikes me, is that we wasted half that money on the 2000's building/refinance boom, and the other half has gone straight to the top (in terms of e.g. a higher stock market). Think of if instead we had invested that money in say infrastructure and research. We all might have been a lot better off. But heaven forbid that the Republicans let that happen.

I'm not sure, but it's at least an interesting contention.

Now I understand why American workers get the shaft: " In fact, trying to eliminate the trade deficit could mean giving up some of the key levers of power that allow the United States to get its way in international politics."

We have sold our nation down a rathole in order to play politics. It's easy to destroy the jobs, etc. of out citizens in favor of foreign relations. Does anyone wonder why the public is so hostile to this insanity? As for liberal always spouting off about inequality how about ending practices that lead to so much of it such as trade, mass immigration, etc. that transfer so much wealth to the top. No wonder Trump and Sander terrify our ruling class.

The author poses, "So does a trade deficit mean fewer jobs? It depends on which force is more economically powerful: fewer jobs creating exports or investment dollars flowing into the country."
I believe it was Studs Terkel who said that he preferred to give money directly to beggars (regardless of how they might use it), rather than give it to charities. This way he could be sure that 100% of his donation would reach its target. Using financial repercussions from outsourcing to bring jobs back seems like a Rube Goldberg to me. And what's to keep newly created jobs from going the same route? What's the point of learning a transient profession anyway? It's very inefficient - and social assistance alternatives are costly to the state and to the psychology of the recipient.

.
On the subject of 58 v. 59, it would seem each of you has made a noteworthy Declaration.
Huh? Did you forget Bush Sr and Bush Jr (2004)?

Pagans are beings who believe in multiple gods rather than One God, the Creator of this and all planets.  Paganism pre-existed Christianity and exists in places Christianity has never reached, including, perhaps, other planets.  The paganism or any religion of aliens would have to survive intellectual and technological developments that allowed them to reach other planets around other stars.  I think that is where your enterprise ran into problems.

You are describing polytheism. Pagan is a term that essentially means non-Christian, and where you have non-Christians, you have Christians. You confuse yourself when you refer to Paganism pre-existing Christianity. Yes, there are and were non-Christian religions that came before Christianity. But, when you refer to them as pagan you are implicitly calling them non-Christian, regardless of where they fit in history. It's kind of like calling a people non-white. It only has meaning if there are white people. If there were no whites you'd just call them... People.

The idea that if an atheist is honest about it he must necessarily own up to having doubts is a concept constructed by a religious world view. It could be the faith talking, or the lost faith talking, but it is clearly not the voice of those who have never had faith and find the very notion risible.

I once set out to cowrite a fantasy novel with the son of a minister. We immediately ran into difficulty while trying to outline the local religion. My coauthor kept referring to the aliens as pagans. When I objected that they could only be pagans if somewhere on this planet there were Christians the project withered and died.

The author of this piece is suffering from a similar misconception when he says: "We can all exist along a continuum of doubt. Some of us will approach religious certainty at one extreme and others will approach atheistic certainty at the other extreme. Many of us will slide back and forth over time."

And the actual atheists have better things to do and don't bother worrying about invisible friends.

Rd Mn, you might want to expand your realm of seeking answers to include history. Religious people don't need to unhand our democracy considering religious people gave us our democracy and warned us it couldn't be maintained without a religiously based moral code. They even based the existence of our most basic rights to life, liberty and the pursuit of happiness on the self evidence and gifting of a creator. Without this religious assumption, from where do you suppose our unalienable rights come? And if they are not mandated by a creator existing above us and our government, do governments have the responsibility to secure them if a majority or controlling, violent minority chose not to recognize those rights. And if that becomes the situation would that be moral, since a truly atheistic society has no moral standard other than the prevailing majority?  In an atheistic society there are no true minority rights... Unless the majority recognizes them because there is no standard above the majority to whom a member of the minority can appeal. One can reason and debate, but without a higher creator and morality giver, there is nothing to claim the majority is wrong if they refuse to recognize your right. But that is the real appeal of atheism, the moral superiority of placing yourself as the sole moral standard. If I must choose you or God as the standard of proof of my unalienable rights I, like the religious founding fathers, choose God.
The noise word God is no more difficult or easy to define than the noise word Consciousness. Qua, Qua, Quack.

Qua, qua, quack.   Why do people persist in using this noise word 'God'?   Until the word is defined, it's part of speech specified, until the author can tell us what possible meaning this word that he insists on writing - could possibly have, then he should remain silent.  Wittgenstein: Whereof one cannot speak, thereof one must be silent.  You might as well be saying "Even an atheist must have doubts about Quack, and there must be moments when he wonders about Quack.  It's just a lot of gabble.  There is no doubt because there is no subject.  There is no answer because there is no question.   It's all noise.

There is a massive surplus of tech and science graduates in this country, but US firm refuse to pay the going rate and prefer cheaper imported workers be it roofing or IT jobs. Wonder what the fired workers from Disney will end up doing?

No matter what anyone has to say here we are finally having a conversation the powers to be have sought to avoid. Thank you Mr Trump and thank you New York Times for this series of article that have reinforced everything Trump has claimed. As one of those sacrificed on the alter of globalism and corporatism I say go Mr. trump.

Eric, "there is no evidence that a God of any kind exists"?

What if one defined "god" as the original cause of time being launched, then the logical coming into existence of time-space and matter? And not asserting this originality has human characteristics, or any characteristics known to humans?

It would be so much simpler, and logical, for there to be nothing instead of the "something" we believe we observe and experience.

There must be an explanation for our "something," right? Does it do harm to label it "god" without attributing to it any personality or intentions?

That's what I do. God created this existence I think I experience. I can leave it at that. I don't need to paint a picture of this "god." And I don't need to assume it imposes any expectations or rules on me. It started, I resulted. I will go away, it's creation will continue. So what?

"Research has shown that science does not have all the answers."  Science provides us with a way to rationalize our world by rules or probability.  It does not give us anything else.  So to the big question why, or where from, no answer.  We could all be hooked up to a computer as in the movie the Matrix.  We don't know.   A belief in God is an optimistic way to say the Universe came from somewhere.  We have been wondering about that since we became sentient.

Um. China has 80% of the mining concessions in Zimbabwe. There is 80% unemployment in Zimbabwe. Cyanide used in mining is used to poison elephants and to stop the vultures from alerting Rangers to game poached. This might be a good place for China to invest in people and animals. It is sorely needed.

Lot of talk here about ones and done---and justly so.  Makes Oklahoma's success more impressive.  4 Seniors in the starting lineup.  The starters have started in 104 consecutive games.  That is a real program.  Congratulations to Lon Kruger and the Sooners.

I can't speak for other non theists, but I believe justice and fairness and compassion are desirable and needed qualities not because god says so but because they just are. I don't feel they have to be justified by some external authority or deity, to me they stand alone as worthy ideals irrespective of any religion or god.

They come from common sense.

Here are my questions for all the atheists commenters like Rd Mn from NJ who are denouncing religion and religious influences in our democracy and society. It was a religious people who signed the document that gave us the religious statement that we are all equal and possess unalienable rights to life, liberty and the pursuit of happiness because we are created that way and our creator gifts us with those rights. These predominantly religious people then proceeded to establish our democratic republic to secure these rights. Throughout our history various minorities have pointed to these truths as proof and defense of their rights.

Define for me where minority rights come from in an atheistic society. If there is no moral standard above us or our government, how can any right exist without the acceptance of the majority or a dictatorial minority? And if there is no moral standard above us or the government is it wrong for the majority to deny a minority these rights? In the absence of a creator , from where does my or your unalienable right to life or Liberty come? And if it is simply us that grant them, can't we just as morally take them away? And if that is the case are they unalienable?

I applaud Professor Irwin's call for open-mindedness, which is so often lacking among the faithful of many faiths, not excluding Christianity.

May we someday overcome the curse of an ideology (religion in all of its variants) which justifies suicide bombing, genital mutilation of children, racism and oppression of women. Here's hoping.

One thing believers apparently don't get: God is something to believe or not believe in only for those who acknowledge it. For the rest of us it's just a historical epiphenomenon that can be explained but will probably wither away with the age of reason.
Ok. How about you keep your mind open? Let's suppose that the God exists but it's a mad genocidal maniac?

The Atheist commenters here only fuel the thesis of this excellent piece.  They are the equivalent of fundamentalists who believe with absolute certainty that their version of God is the One and Only way.  Only when we approach each other with humility will there be any dialogue but humility is no longer a virtue in American society and certainly not in our politics yet it is the cornerstone of all religion.
